PART II - STILLWATER CITY CODE 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Stillwater City Code" and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Stillwater Code." 
(Code 1982, § 1-1) 
Charter reference- Codification, § 2-16. 
State Law reference- Codification of ordinances, 11 O.S. §§ 14-107, 14-108; compilation and publication of penal ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-109. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Charter. The term "Charter" means the Charter of the City of Stillwater, as ratified at an election held on December 13, 1960, as amended, which is printed as part I of this volume. 
    City. The term " city" means the City of Stillwater in Payne County, Oklahoma. 
    City council. The term "city council" or "council" means the City Council of the City of Stillwater, Oklahoma, as established in the Charter. 
Charter reference- Form of government, § 1-2. 
    Code. Reference to " Code" means the Stillwater City Code, as designated in section 1-1 of this Code. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be excluded in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be included, unless it is a legal holiday as defined by 25 O.S. § 82.1. 
State Law reference- Computation of time, 12 O.S. § 2006. 
    County. The term "county," means Payne County, Oklahoma. 
    Delegation of authority. A provision that authorizes or requires a city officer or employee to perform an act or make a decision authorizes such officer or employee to act or make a decision through subordinates. 
    Gender. A term importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Highway. The term "highway" includes any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Joint authority. Terms purporting to give authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 31. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 23. 
    Number. Any term importing singular number shall include the plural and any term importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 25. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and, in such cases, the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
State Law reference- Affirmation generally, 12 O.S. § 72. 
    Officers, departments, etc. Except as otherwise specifically provided, whenever any officer, department, board, commission or other agency is referred to by title alone, such reference is construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Stillwater, Oklahoma." 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" extends and is applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the term "person," as applied to partnerships or associations, means the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean "next before" and "next after," respectively. 
    Roadway. The term "roadway" means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Shall, may. The term "shall" is mandatory, and the term "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State. The term " state" means the State of Oklahoma. 
    Statutory references. Reference to the statutes of the State of Oklahoma means the statutes as they now are or as they may be amended, and a reference to the statutes also means the comparable provision when included in future codifications or supplementations of the statutes. All state statutes shall be referenced as, for example, 11 O.S. § 14-108. 
    Street. The term "street" includes any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place, square, bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Tense. Terms used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" includes any representations of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1966, §§ 11-1-11-5; Code 1982, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1982, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-4. - References to sections. 
    All references in this Code to chapters, articles, divisions or sections are to chapters, articles, divisions or sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
(Code 1982, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-6. - Editor's notes and other references. 
    All editor's notes, charter references, and state law references in this Code are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and are not of any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(2)  Any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of taxes or for an annual budget; 
(3)  Any ordinance creating specific sewer and paving districts and other local improvement districts or otherwise relating to specific local improvements and special assessments therefor; 
(4)  Any ordinance calling or otherwise relating to specific elections; 
(5)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city or excluding territory as a part of the city; 
(6)  Any ordinance granting any franchise, permit or other right; 
(7)  Any ordinance accepting the beneficial interest in any trust created by a trust indenture; 
(8)  Any ordinance creating a trust or relating thereto; 
(9)  Any ordinance approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to any contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument; 
(10)  Any rezoning ordinance or regulations or ordinance approving a subdivision plat; 
(11)  Any temporary or special ordinance; 
(12)  Any ordinance regarding fees, deposits, rates or charges levied by the city which are in effect, but not included in this Code; 
(13)  Any ordinance regarding compensation, benefits, retirement programs, and personnel policies regarding officers and employees; 
(b)  All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1982, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-8. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
Sec. 1-10. - Application of Code to outlying real property. 
    All ordinances shall apply to all real property belonging to, or under the control of the city outside the corporate limits of the city, and shall be in full effect therein insofar as they are applicable. All ordinances of the city which shall go into effect in the future, shall also apply to, and be in full effect within the boundaries of all said outlying real property, insofar as they may be applicable. Any words in any ordinance indicating that the effect of an ordinance provision is limited to the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed to mean and include also the said outlying real property belonging to, or under the control of, the city, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(Code 1982, § 1-7; Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 12-16-1974) 
Sec. 1-11. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  Any additions or amendments to this Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city council to make them a part of this Code, are incorporated in this Code so that a reference to this Code shall be understood as including them. All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Stillwater City Code is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Stillwater City Code is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered, _____ which said section reads as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1982, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Enactment of ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-103 et seq. 
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code, and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during the period. The pages of the supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____ (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-11) 
State Law reference- Adoption and revision of codes of ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-107-14-109. 
Sec. 1-13. - Severability of parts of Code and ordinances. 
    If a court of competent jurisdiction should hold one or more sections or a part of a section of this Code or of an ordinance passed hereafter invalid, such holding shall not affect the remainder of the Code or ordinance nor the context in which such section, sections or part of a section so held invalid may appear, except to the extent that an entire section or part of a section may be inseparably connected in meaning and effect with the section, sections or part of a section so held invalid. 
(Code 1966, § 11-6; Code 1982, § 1-12) 
Sec. 1-14. - Penalties for violation of Code. 
    Whenever in this Code or in other ordinance of the city, or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him, or it, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful, it shall be a misdemeanor unless otherwise specifically stated; and where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the city, or such rule, regulation, or order, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  If the violation is a Class A offense, it shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $750.00 and costs, and/or by imprisonment not exceeding 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment; 
(2)  If the violation is a Class B offense, it shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $200.00 and costs; 
(3)  If the violation is a Class C offense, it shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 and costs; 
(4)  If the violation is a Class D offense, it shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 and costs, and/or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or, by both such fine and imprisonment. 
    If any act or omission is declared to be a Class A, Class B, Class C, or Class D offense, it shall be punishable as indicated above. In the absence of any other penalty, an offense shall be a Class C offense. 
    Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, administrative adjudication and revocation of licenses or permits. 
(Code 1966, §§ 7-2, 14-1; Code 1982, § 1-8; Ord. No. 1576, § 2, 6-7-1975; Ord. No. 1645, § 10, 6-21-1976; Ord. No. 2095, § 1, 9-19-1983; Ord. No. 2388, § 1, 9-17-1990; Ord. No. 2715, § 1, 7-9-2001; Ord. No. 2750, § 1, 5-13-2002; Ord. No. 3149, § 1, 9-19-2011, eff. 10-1-2011) 
State Law reference- Penalty authority, 11 O.S. § 14-111; jurisdiction of criminal court not of record, 11 O.S. § 27-103; arrests and bail, 11 O.S. §§ 27-117, 27.117.1. 
Sec. 1-15. - Imposition of penalty does not preclude civil action. 
    No penalty imposed by and pursuant to any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city shall interfere with the right of the city to also apply to the proper court for a mandamus, an injunction or other appropriate action against the person against whom the penalty is imposed. 
(Code 1982, § 1-9) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- City manager and administrative departments, etc., art. III. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Tort claims; workers' compensation claims; payment. 
    The city manager is authorized to settle and pay tort claims and workers' compensation claims valued at less than $50,000.00 without prior city council approval, upon recommendation of the city attorney. The city council shall by resolution adopt guidelines for the processing of claims before the city manager may exercise authority granted under this section. 
(Code 1982, § 2-7; Ord. No. 2933, § 1, 2-27-2006; Ord. No. 3192, § 1, 9-6-2012; Ord. No. 3338, § 1, 4-4-2016 ) 
State Law reference- Tort Claims Act, 51 O.S. § 151 et seq. 
Sec. 2-2. - City clerk. 
    The city clerk shall be appointed by the city council for an indefinite term. The clerk shall work under the general direction of the city manager, or designee, as set forth in Section 3.3 of the City Charter and shall be subject to suspension or removal by the city manager in accordance with said section. 
    The city clerk shall serve as clerical officer of the city council. He or she shall keep the journal of its proceedings, and shall enroll in a book or books kept for the purpose all ordinances and resolutions passed by it. The clerk shall be custodian of such documents, records and archives as may be provided by applicable law or ordinance; shall be custodian of the seal of the city; and shall attest, and affix the seal to, documents when required in accordance with applicable law or ordinance. 
( Ord. No. 3309, § 1, 7-6-2015 ) 
Secs. 2-3-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- City council, art II. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-21-2-43. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS AND PUBLIC HEARINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Meetings, § 2-7; quorum and procedure, § 2-11. 

Sec. 2-44. - Regular meetings. 
    The city council shall establish an annual regular meeting schedule in accordance with the Oklahoma Open Meeting Act, 25 O.S. § 301 et seq., and the city Charter. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1; Code 1982, § 2-16; Ord. No. 1528, § 1(a), 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2845, § 1, 11-8-2004; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005; Ord. No. 3074, § 1, 8-31-2009) 
Charter reference- Regular and special city council meetings, § 2-7. 
State Law reference- Meetings open to the public, 25 O.S. § 301 et seq. 
Sec. 2-45. - Open meetings. 
    All meetings of the city council shall be opened to the public pursuant to the statutes of the state and the city Charter. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.5; Code 1982, § 2-17; Ord. No. 1575, § 1, 8-18-1975; Ord. No. 2018, § 1, 7-19-1982; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Open Meeting Act, 25 O.S. § 301 et seq. 
Sec. 2-46. - Agenda. 
    All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, contract documents, or other matters to be submitted to the city council shall be delivered to the city manager whereupon he shall arrange a list of such matters according to the order of business and furnish each member of the city council and the city attorney with a copy prior to the city council meeting and as far in advance of the meeting as time for preparation will permit. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.1; Code 1982, § 2-18; Ord. No. 1528, § 2, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
State Law reference- Posting of agenda, 25 O.S. § 311(9). 
Sec. 2-47. - Presiding officer. 
(a)  The mayor, or in his absence, the vice mayor, shall take the chair precisely at the hour appointed for the meeting and shall immediately call the city council to order. In the absence of the mayor and vice mayor, the city manager or acting city manager shall call the city council to order, whereupon an acting chair shall be elected by the members of the council present. Upon the arrival of the mayor or vice mayor, the acting chair shall immediately relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the business immediately pending before the city council. 
(b)  The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular and special meetings of the council. He shall state every question coming before the city council, call upon the city manager for any appropriate background information and recommendations, announce the decision of the city council on all subjects and decide all questions of order, subject, however, to an appeal by the city council, in which event a majority vote of the city council shall govern and conclusively determine such questions of order. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.2; Code 1982, § 2-19; Ord. No. 1528, § 3, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-48. - Order of business. 
(a)  Promptly at the hour set by law on the day of each regular meeting, the members of the city council, the city manager, the city attorney and the deputy city clerk shall take their regular stations in the city council chambers; and the business of the city council shall be taken up for consideration and disposition in the following order: 
(1)  Roll call. 
(2)  Approval of minutes of previous meeting. 
(3)  Approval of consent agenda items. 
(4)  Public comment on agenda items not scheduled for public hearing. 
(5)  Items removed from the consent agenda. 
(6)  Public hearings. 
(7)  General orders. 
(8)  Resolutions. 
(9)  Ordinances. 
(10)  Reports from officers. 
(11)  Questions and inquiries. 
(12)  Appointments. 
(13)  Adjournment. 
(b)  The presiding officer may alter the order of business during a meeting whenever necessary. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.5; Code 1982, § 2-20; Ord. No. 1575, § 1, 8-18-1975; Ord. No. 2018, § 1, 7-19-1982; Ord. No. 2193, § 1, 5-13-1985; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005; Ord. No. 3074, § 2, 8-31-2009; Ord. No. 3110, § 1, 9-20-2010) 
Sec. 2-49. - Roll call. 
    Before processing the business of the city council, the city clerk or deputy city clerk shall take the roll of the members and the names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.3; Code 1982, § 2-21; Ord. No. 1528, § 4, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-50. - Reading of minutes. 
    Unless a reading of the minutes of a city council meeting is requested by a member of the city council, such minutes may be approved without reading. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.4; Code 1982, § 2-22; Ord. No. 1528, § 5, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
State Law reference- Minutes required, 25 O.S. § 312. 
Sec. 2-51. - Voting; quorum. 
(a)  Unless specifically provided by applicable statute or ordinance, an "abstain" vote shall not be deemed a negative vote. 
(b)  A majority of the quorum shall be sufficient to render a decision, unless the applicable state statute or city ordinance requires a greater number. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.6; Code 1982, § 2-23; Ord. No. 1528, § 7, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2029, § 1, 9-20-1982; Ord. No. 2155, § 1, 10-22-1984; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-52. - Rules of debate. 
(a)  The mayor or vice mayor, or such other member of the city council as may be presiding, may move, second and debate from the chair, subject only to such limitations of debate as are by these rules imposed on all members and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of a city councilor by reason of his acting as the presiding officer. 
(b)  Every member desiring to speak shall address the chair and shall be recognized by the presiding officer, shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. 
(c)  A member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call him to order or as herein otherwise provided. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, he shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined, and, if in order, he shall be permitted to proceed. 
(d)  The councilor proposing adoption of an ordinance or resolution shall have the privilege of closing the debate on said ordinance or resolution. 
(e)  A motion to reconsider any action taken by the city council may be made only on the day such action was taken or at the next meeting of city council, whether a regular or special meeting. Such motion must be made by one of the prevailing side, but may be seconded by any member and may be made at any time and have precedence over all other motions or while a member has the floor; it shall be debatable. No vote may be taken on a motion to reconsider until notice is provided in accordance with the Oklahoma Open Meeting Act, 25 O.S. § 301 et seq. 
(f)  The city council may grant the privilege of having an abstract of any individual city councilor's statement on any subject under consideration by the city council entered in the minutes. 
(g)  The city clerk may be directed by the presiding officer, with consent of the city council, to enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming before the city council as a part of that particular meetings regular and normal city council meeting agenda. 
(h)  After motion and second having been properly entered and made, the city council, by a majority vote, may limit debate on any particular agenda item before the city council. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.7; Code 1982, § 2-24; Ord. No. 1528, § 8, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-53. - Public addressing the council, generally. 
(a)  Taxpayers or residents of the city, or their authorized legal representatives, may address the council at a regularly-scheduled meeting on any item of business listed on the meeting agenda, in accordance with this division. 
(b)  Requests to address the city council shall be submitted in writing to the city clerk prior to the start of the council meeting. The city manager or designee shall prepare and distribute a form for this purpose. Only those persons that have complied with this requirement will be permitted to speak at the meeting. 
(c)  Each person addressing the council shall step up to the microphone and shall give his name and address in an audible tone of voice for the record. Such person shall be entitled to speak one time only at the meeting on any item of business, for three minutes, unless further time is granted by the presiding officer after consultation with the council. All remarks shall be addressed to the council as a body and not to any member thereof. No person other than the council and the person with the floor shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, either directly or through a member of the council, without permission of the presiding officer after consultation with the council. No questions shall be asked a councilor except through the presiding officer. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.8; Code 1982, § 2-25; Ord. No. 1528, § 9, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005; Ord. No. 3704, § 3, 8-31-2009; Ord. No. 3110, § 2, 9-20-2010) 
Sec. 2-54. - Public hearings. 
(a)  The city council shall hold a public hearing open to all citizens and interested parties when required to do so by state statute or city ordinance. The city council may order the holding of such other public hearings as it finds necessary and in the best interests of the city. When the council shall direct that a special hearing be held, notice shall be given in accordance with the applicable state statute or city ordinance. All public hearings shall be proceedings of relative formality, open to the public, with specific issues of fact or of law to be heard, and shall be much the same as trials, in that a public hearing may terminate with the issuance of a final order. 
(b)  The public hearing shall be convened by the presiding officer identifying the subject of the hearing. The presiding officer shall then inquire as to the sufficiency of notification and direct the city manager or designee to present appropriate background information to the council. The presiding officer shall next solicit comment from any interested person or authorized representative regarding the subject of said hearing. If the hearing is an individual proceeding, the presiding officer shall utilize the following order of business: 
(1)  Comments from persons or authorized representatives in favor of the subject of the hearing; 
(2)  Comments from persons or authorized representatives in opposition to the subject of the hearing; 
(3)  Rebuttal or surrebuttal, if deemed necessary by the presiding officer after consultation with the council; 
(4)  Once the presiding officer has determined that public comment is complete, he shall announce that the hearing is closed, and the council may then commence deliberation. 
(c)  Comments from persons or authorized representatives shall be limited to five minutes in length, unless the presiding officer after consultation with the council, determines that a different time limit is more appropriate. No person or authorized representative may speak more than once at the hearing unless requested by the council to do so. 
(d)  The council shall refrain from debate during public comment. However, a councilor may ask questions of any speaker for the purpose of clarifying a representation made during a presentation. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.9; Code 1982, § 2-26; Ord. No. 1575, § 2, 8-18-1975; Ord. No. 2194, § 1, 6-3-1985; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005; Ord. No. 3074, § 4, 8-31-2009) 
Sec. 2-55. - Decorum. 
(a)  While the city council is in session, the members must preserve order and decorum and a member shall neither by conversation or otherwise delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the city council or disturb any member while speaking or refuse to obey the orders of the city council. 
(b)  Any person making personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks or who shall become boisterous while addressing the city council shall be forthwith by the presiding officer barred and removed from further audience before the city council unless permission to continue is granted by a majority vote of the city council. 
(c)  The chief of police or such members of the police department as he may so designate, shall be sergeant-at-arms at city council meetings. They shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at city council meetings, upon instructions of the presiding officer, unless overruled by a majority vote of the city council. It shall be the duty of the sergeant-at-arms to place any person who violates the order and decorum of the meeting under arrest and cause him to be prosecuted under the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.10; Code 1982, § 2-27; Ord. No. 1528, § 11, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-56. - Basis for determining voting result; filing of reasons. 
(a)  All matters coming before the city council, whether they are ordinances, contracts, resolutions, or matters of parliamentary procedure, and on which a vote is taken, shall require a majority vote before said matter shall pass. A tie vote shall be considered "no decision." 
(b)  Upon the conclusion of any vote so taken, any member of the city council shall have the right to have the reasons for his vote entered upon the minutes. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.11; Code 1982, § 2-28; Ord. No. 1638, § 1, 6-1-1978; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-57. - Motion to table. 
    A motion to table any matter then under consideration except during a public hearing shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.13; Code 1982, § 2-29; Ord. No. 1528, § 14, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-58. - Adjournment. 
    A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.14; Code 1982, § 2-30; Ord. No. 1528, § 15, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-59. - Parliamentarian. 
    The city attorney shall serve as parliamentarian. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.17; Code 1982, § 2-31; Ord. No. 1528, § 18, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-60. - Robert's Rules of order. 
    All questions of law, questions of procedure, or questions of fact which may present themselves to the city council and which are not covered by the provisions of this article may be resolved by consulting a recognized parliamentary procedures manual such as "Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised." 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.18; Code 1982, § 2-32; Ord. No. 1528, § 19, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2889, § 1, 8-15-2005) 
Secs. 2-61-2-78. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS, CONTRACTS, ETC.[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Adoption procedure, §§ 2-12-2-16. 

Sec. 2-79. - Preparation of ordinances and resolutions. 
    All ordinances and resolutions shall be prepared by and approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.12; Code 1982, § 2-41; Ord. No. 1528, § 13(a), 8-12-1974) 
Sec. 2-80. - Introduction of ordinances and resolutions. 
    Any ordinance or resolution may be introduced and sponsored by a member of the city council, the city manager, or city attorney and any member of the city council may assume the sponsorship thereof by moving same on first reading. Every ordinance shall be introduced in writing and after passage on first reading shall be made available for examination by any and all parties in the office of the city clerk. The city clerk shall maintain a record of each ordinance introduced to the city council and whether such ordinance was adopted. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.12(b), (c); Code 1982, § 2-42; Ord. No. 1528, § 13(b), (c), 8-12-1974) 
Sec. 2-81. - Passage and approval of ordinances. 
(a)  Following the advancement of any ordinance on first reading, any councilor may request a public hearing on such ordinance prior to consideration for final adoption. 
(b)  Following the advancement of any ordinance from first reading, at a subsequent meeting such ordinance shall be read by title only, unless the city council by majority vote requests that said ordinance be read in full, and considered and following such consideration the city council may pass such ordinance with or without amendments. The passage of any ordinance pursuant to section 2-13 of the Charter shall be final and no further passage shall be required. 
(c)  An emergency ordinance may be adopted pursuant to section 2-14 of the Charter. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.2; Code 1982, § 2-43; Ord. No. 1528, § 13(d), 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 2195, § 1, 6-3-1985) 
Sec. 2-82. - Approval of contracts or agreements. 
    Contracts or agreements which seek to bind the city may be approved by resolution or by simple motion which shall be adopted by a majority vote of the city council. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.12; Code 1982, § 2-44; Ord. No. 1528, § 13(f), 8-12-1974) 
Sec. 2-83. - Introduction and passage of resolutions. 
    A resolution may be adopted at the meeting at which it is introduced. It may be introduced orally and following adoption may be reduced to writing in a form approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.12; Code 1982, § 2-45; Ord. No. 1528, § 13(e), 8-12-1974) 
Sec. 2-84. - Execution of ordinances, resolutions and agreements. 
    Upon final passage and adoption of any ordinance, resolution, contract or agreement, the mayor shall sign all such ordinances, resolutions, contracts and agreements adopted by the city council in his presence and the city clerk, or deputy city clerk, shall attest to his signature. In the event of the absence of the mayor, the vice-mayor shall sign such ordinances, resolutions, contracts or agreements as then adopted. 
(Code 1966, § 1-1.12; Code 1982, § 2-46; Ord. No. 1528, § 13(g), 8-12-1974) 
Secs. 2-85-2-111. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AUTHORITIES, BOARDS, COMMITTEES, COMMISSIONS, TRUSTS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Library board, § 3-6. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-112. - General rules of procedure. 
    Unless otherwise provided by city ordinance or bylaws approved by resolution passed by four-fifths of the city council, the rules of procedure set forth in sections 2-45 through 2-47 and sections 2-49 through 2-59 of this Code shall govern and be applicable to the proceedings of any authority, board, commission, committee or trust established by the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 2-35; Ord. No. 2889, § 2, 8-15-2005; Ord. No. 2958, § 1, 9-18-2006) 
Sec. 2-113. - Appointment; procedure. 
    Unless otherwise provided by city ordinance, members of all authorities, boards, commissions, or trusts shall be appointed by the city council whenever vacancies occur. The mayor shall have the privilege of nominating persons to fill such vacancies and the city council shall have the right to accept or reject any such nomination, or to select any other person it deems suitable to fill the vacancy. 
(Code 1982, § 2-36; Ord. No. 2889, § 2, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-114. - Members; qualifications; removal. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided by city ordinance, members of all authorities, boards, commissions, committees or trusts shall be residents of the city. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided by city ordinance, members of all authorities, boards, commissions, committees or trusts shall serve until a qualified successor is appointed. 
(c)  Members of all authorities, boards, committees, commissions or trusts serve at the pleasure of the city council and may be removed from office at any time for any reason. 
(d)  The city manager shall serve as an ex officio member to all authorities, boards, commissions, committees or trusts established by the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 2-37; Ord. No. 2889, § 2, 8-15-2005; Ord. No. 3156, § 1, 1-19-2012) 
Sec. 2-115. - Officers; selection; tenure; bylaws. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided by city ordinance or bylaws approved by resolution passed by four-fifths of the city council, members of all authorities, boards, commissions, committees or trusts shall annually select from their membership a chair and vice-chair. 
(b)  The chair, or in his absence vice-chair, shall serve as presiding officer at all meetings. 
(c)  The membership of any authority, board, commission, committee or trust may adopt bylaws to govern procedures and establish offices in addition to those specifically provided for by city ordinance. Any such bylaws will become effective upon adoption of a resolution passed by four-fifths of the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 2-38; Ord. No. 2889, § 2, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-116. - City council review of decisions. 
(a)  The city council shall have the right to review any decision of an authority, board, commission, committees or trust upon application of an aggrieved party or city staff and the affirmative vote of three city councilors. This provision shall not apply to quasi-judicial rulings by the board of adjustment, building trades board, board of drainage appeals, or any other entity authorized by state statute or city ordinance to make such determinations; to decisions of public trusts; or whenever city ordinance provides a specific review or appeal procedure. Authority to review under this section must be invoked by the city council no later than the second regular city council meeting following the date that the decision to be reviewed was rendered by the authority, board or commission. 
(b)  Whenever the city council decides to exercise this authority, a hearing date shall be scheduled no less than ten days from the date the city council votes to review the decision. Written notice shall be sent to all parties involved in the decision below, and the city clerk shall certify to the city council that said notice was received by said persons before the hearing may commence. 
(c)  The city council shall review the decision de novo and shall have the right to affirm, reverse, modify, or remand any decision reviewed. 
(Code 1982, § 2-39; Ord. No. 2889, § 2, 8-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-117. - Authority of members. 
    All authorities, boards, commissions, committees or trusts established by the city council shall exercise their official duties as an entity at meetings convened pursuant to applicable state statutes and city ordinances. No member has authority to act or otherwise conduct business on behalf of the authority, board, commission, trust, or city, or to direct the activities of city staff, outside of a properly convened meeting. 
(Code 1982, § 2-40; Ord. No. 2889, § 2, 8-15-2005) 
Secs. 2-118-2-147. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AUDIT COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-148. - Membership. 
(a)  The audit committee shall consist of five voting members who shall be appointed by the city council and three nonvoting ex officio members. 
(b)  The five voting members shall include not less than one person from each of the following groups, provided, however, that one group, which may vary from time to time, may be represented by not more than two members: 
(1)  Bankers, or other financial institutions; 
(2)  Business persons; and 
(3)  Certified public accountants. 
(c)  The three ex officio, nonvoting members shall be a city councilor, the city manager and the director of finance. 
(Code 1966, §§ 6-42, 6-43; Code 1982, § 2-114; Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 2890, § 1, 6-27-2005) 
Sec. 2-149. - Purpose. 
    It is the responsibility of the audit committee to provide independent review and oversight of the government's financial reporting processes, internal controls and independent auditors. 
(Code 1966, § 6-40; Code 1982, § 2-115; Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 3382, § 7, 9-18-2017 ) 
Sec. 2-150. - Functions. 
    The duties of the audit committee shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Recommendation of accounting firm to perform the annual audit; 
(2)  Maintenance of good communications with city staff and independent accountants; 
(3)  Review and evaluation of year end financial statements and independent accountants' audit reports; 
(4)  Review and evaluation of independent accountants' management letter; 
(5)  Review any reported deficiencies in internal control; and 
(6)  To report to the city council as required. 
(Code 1966, § 6-41; Code 1982, § 2-116; Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 3382, § 7, 9-18-2017 ) 
Secs. 2-151-2-168. - Reserved.

DIVISION 4. - STILLWATER SISTER CITIES COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-202. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created the Stillwater Sister Cities Council, which shall be composed of 11 members. 
(Code 1982, § 2-180; Ord. No. 2274, § 2, 12-1-1986; Ord. No. 2554, § 1, 12-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-203. - Membership. 
    The city council shall appoint the members of the sister cities council, each of whom shall serve without compensation. At least one sister cities councilmember shall be a member of the sister cities youth chapter. In addition to the appointed members, the city manager or his designated representative shall serve as an ex officio, nonvoting member, and shall be the secretary/treasurer of the sister cities council. 
(Code 1982, § 2-181; Ord. No. 2274, § 2, 12-1-1986) 
Sec. 2-204. - Term of office. 
    The members of the sister cities council shall be appointed for staggered terms and shall serve for a term of three years or until his successor is appointed. The terms of all members shall expire on November 3 in the year in which the term would ordinarily expire, regardless of the date of appointment. Members serve at the pleasure of the city council and are subject to removal at any time for any reason. 
(Code 1982, § 2-182; Ord. No. 2274, § 2, 12-1-1986; Ord. No. 2554, § 2, 12-16-1996; Ord. No. 2856, § 1, 1-31-2005) 
Sec. 2-205. - Quorum. 
    Six members of the sister cities council shall constitute a quorum, and business may be transacted by a simple majority of a quorum. 
(Code 1982, § 2-183; Ord. No. 2274, § 2, 12-1-1986; Ord. No. 2554, § 3, 12-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-206. - Chair; meetings. 
    The sister cities council shall select from its members a chair who shall serve for a period of one year, ending November 3. The meetings and hearings of the sister cities council shall be called by the chair. Members shall be given five days' notice prior to any meeting; provided, emergency meetings may be held if all members consent to such meetings. All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Oklahoma Open Meeting Act, 25 O.S. § 301 et seq. 
(Code 1982, § 2-184; Ord. No. 2274, § 2, 12-1-1986) 
Sec. 2-207. - Duties. 
    The sister cities council shall: 
(1)  Make recommendations to the city council regarding sister cities activities. 
(2)  Coordinate the official activities of the sister cities program which include cultural, professional, educational, and youth exchange programs; international economic trade and development activities; and exchange student programs. 
(3)  Initiate special sister cities activities as requested by the city council. 
(4)  Initiate public information activities designed to keep citizens informed of sister cities activities and encourage the greatest community involvement possible in the sister cities program. 
(5)  When appropriate, complement and assist the activities of other community groups which are involved in international exchange projects. 
(Code 1982, § 2-185; Ord. No. 2274, § 2, 12-1-1986) 
Secs. 2-208-2-237. - Reserved.

DIVISION 9. - RURAL WATER ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-349. - Membership. 
(a)  The rural water advisory board shall consist of seven members. 
(1)  Initially, all seven members shall reside in the geographical area located outside the corporate limits of the city served by Rural Water Corporation #3, Payne County, Oklahoma (RWC#3), as said area existed on October 1, 2006. 
(2)  At such time, if any, that the city and/or the city utilities authority assumes maintenance and/or operational responsibility for any additional rural water provider, then the existing board shall be dissolved and a new board comprised of representatives from RWC#3 and the additional rural water provider shall be formed. The board shall then consist of nine members. 
(3)  At such time, if any, that the city and/or the city utilities authority assumes maintenance and/or operational responsibility for two or more rural water providers in addition to RWC#3, the board shall be reconstituted so that representatives from all such rural water providers shall be members of the board, which shall then consist of 11 members. 
(4)  At such time, if any, that there is more than one rural water provider eligible to be represented, representation on the board shall be apportioned on the basis of the amount of water used within the geographical area previously served by each rural water provider; provided, however, that no rural water provider shall be allocated less than one board member. 
(5)  The unit of representation shall be set forth in bylaws established by the board and adopted by the city council at the time that the first rural water provider in addition to RWC#3 becomes eligible for board membership. The city manager or the city manager's designee shall serve as a nonvoting, ex officio member of the board. 
(b)  Each board member shall be an account holder residing, during his term of service on the board, in the geographical area located outside the corporate limits of the city which was previously served by a rural water provider now operated and/or maintained by the city and/or the city utilities authority. 
(c)  Board members shall be nominated annually by account holders then residing within the geographical area of the former rural water provider or providers represented on the board; provided, that as long as any former rural water provider continues to exist as a legal entity, the rural water provider shall be responsible for nominating members based upon the number of board members allocated to it. All nominations shall be submitted to the city council, which shall appoint all nominees to the board, unless sufficient cause exists to reject any nominee. 
(d)  Board members shall initially be appointed for the following staggered terms: Each member shall serve three-year terms, subject to the requirements set forth in this Code. 
(e)  Whenever the first additional rural water provider becomes eligible for membership in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, board members shall initially be appointed to the following terms: 
(1)  Three members shall be appointed to three-year terms; 
(2)  Three members shall be appointed to two-year terms; and 
(3)  Three members shall be appointed to one-year terms. 
(f)  Thereafter, each member shall serve three-year terms, subject to the requirements set forth in this Code. Whenever the second additional rural water provider becomes eligible for membership in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, board members shall initially be appointed to the following terms: 
(1)  Four members shall be appointed to three-year terms; 
(2)  Four members shall be appointed to two-year terms; and 
(3)  Three members shall be appointed to one-year terms. 
(g)  Thereafter, each member shall serve three-year terms, subject to the requirements set forth in this Code. This process shall be repeated each time an additional rural water provider becomes eligible for membership. 
(Code 1982, § 2-260; Ord. No. 2997, § 1, 6-4-2007) 
Sec. 2-350. - Quorum. 
    Four members of the rural water advisory board shall constitute a quorum and business may be transacted by a simple majority of a quorum. Provided, however, once the total membership on this board is expanded to nine members in accordance with the provisions of section 2-349(a), five members shall constitute a quorum and business may be transacted by a simple majority of a quorum. Provided further, once the total membership of this board is expanded to 11 members in accordance with the provisions of section 2-349(a), six members shall constitute a quorum and business may be transacted by a simple majority of a quorum. 
(Code 1982, § 2-261; Ord. No. 2997, § 1, 6-4-2007) 
Sec. 2-351. - Officers; meetings. 
(a)  The rural water advisory board shall select from its membership a chair and a vice-chair who shall serve for a period of one year. The board shall establish a regular meeting schedule, with meetings held at least monthly. Special meetings may be called by the chair, the vice-chair or the city manager. 
(b)  The board's schedule of meetings, its notices and agendas shall conform to the requirements of the Oklahoma Open Meeting Act, 25 O.S. § 301 et seq. 
(Code 1982, § 2-262; Ord. No. 2997, § 1, 6-4-2007) 
Sec. 2-352. - Powers and duties. 
    The rural water advisory board shall advise and make recommendations to the to the city council on matters pertaining to operation and maintenance of rural water systems operated and/or maintained by the city or the city utilities authority. 
(Code 1982, § 2-263; Ord. No. 2997, § 1, 6-4-2007) 
Secs. 2-353-2-377. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-493. - Service in other cities in emergency. 
(a)  Approval is hereby given for service of members of the regular police department of this city as police officers of any other city or town, in an emergency situation, when such service is requested by the mayor or chief of police of said city or town, in accordance with 11 O.S. § 34-103. 
(b)  Requests for such service shall be made in writing or by telephone, or other means of communication, to the city manager, who, if he determines that the request can be granted consistently with the continuance of the proper police protection to the inhabitants of this city, shall direct the chief of police to furnish the number of officers available and to arrange for their transportation to the requesting municipality. 
(Code 1966, §§ 1-7, 1-7.1; Code 1982, § 25-5; Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 8-13-1973)

Sec. 2-550. - Bond of manager and director of finance. 
(a)  The bond of the city manager shall be $30,000.00. The bond of the director of finance shall be $30,000.00. 
(b)  The form of the bond shall be substantially as follows: 
    STATE OF OKLAHOMA 
    COUNTY OF PAYNE 
    KNOW ALL MEN BY THESE PRESENTS, that we ___________, as principal, and ___________, a corporation of the State of Oklahoma, as surety, are held and firmly bound unto the City of Stillwater and State of Oklahoma in the penal sum of $30,000, for the payment of which we bind ourselves, our heirs, executors successors, and administrators, jointly and severally, firmly by these presents. 
    The condition of the above obligation is: That whereas the above bound _______ has been appointed City Manager in and for the City of Stillwater, Oklahoma. 
    Now, if the said _______ shall render a true account of his office and of the things therein to the proper authority, when required thereby or by law; and shall promptly pay over to the person or officers entitled thereto, all money which may come into his hands by virtue of his said office; and shall faithfully account for all the balances of money remaining in his hands at the termination of his office; and shall hereafter exercise all reasonable diligence and care in the preservation and lawful disposal of all money, books, papers and sureties or other property, appertaining to his said office and deliver them to his successor, or to any person authorized to receive the same; and if he shall faithfully and impartially, without fear, favor, fraud or impression, discharge all other duties now or hereafter required of his office by law, then this bond to be void, otherwise in full force. 
    Signed this ___ day of ___________, A.D. 20___. 
    PRINCIPAL: 
    SURETY: 
    ATTEST: 
    By ___________ 
    Approved by the Stillwater City Council this ___ day of ___________, 20___. 
_____
MAYOR  
(Code 1966, §§ 1-29, 1-30; Code 1982, § 2-1) 
Charter reference- Bond of certain officers, § 9-6. 
State Law reference- Bonds for certain municipal employees required, 11 O.S. § 8-105. 
Sec. 2-551. - Health officer; cooperative health department director.

(Code 1982, § 2-2) 
State Law reference- Cooperative health departments, 63 O.S. § 1-205. 
Sec. 2-552. - Collective bargaining unit agreements. 
    All terms and conditions of any contract or agreement between the city and any labor organization representing city employees shall require city council approval. 
(Ord. No. 3049, §§ 1, 2, 12-1-2009)
