(1)  The developer and/or owner shall lease his interest in the main to the city for a period of ten years, during which time the city will assume responsibility for maintenance of the main as a part of the sanitary sewer system of the city; however, upon written request by the developer and/or owner to the city council, within 90 days prior to the expiration of lease period, the lease period shall be extended for an additional period of ten years if the developer and/or owner has not received, at the expiration of the original lease period, contribution on a square footage basis, as hereinafter described, from the developers and/or owners of at least 50 percent of the area capable of being served by such main; and provided further, if the developer and/or owner has received, at the expiration of the original lease period, contribution on a square footage basis, as hereinafter described, from the developers and/or owners of at least 50 percent but less than 75 percent of the area capable of being served by such main, the city council may, in its sole discretion, extend the lease period for an additional period of not to exceed ten years, upon written request by the developer and/or owner to the city council within the time set forth in this subsection. 
(2)  The city will not permit any person to connect any new or additional main to the main, or make a sewer connection thereto, without first requiring such person to pay to the developer and/or owner his pro rata portion of the original investment of the developer and/or owner in the main, together with interest thereon from the date of completion of the main at a rate not to exceed seven percent per annum, such pro rata portion to be calculated on a square footage basis of the total area capable of being served by such main. The total area capable of being served by such main shall be agreed upon by the developer and/or owner and the city at the time of the execution of the lease-purchase agreement. 
(3)  The developer and/or owner shall have no right or claim to any portion of the revenue received by the city for tie-on charges or service charges; the reimbursement to the developer and/or owner is specifically limited to contribution under subsection (2) of this section. 
(4)  At such time as the developer and/or owner has received contribution on a square footage basis, as described in subsections (1) through (3) of this section, from the developers and/or owner of all the area capable of being served by such main, or at the expiration of the lease period set forth in the lease-purchase agreement, or an extension thereof, as above provided, the title to the sewer main shall vest in the city; and the developer and/or owner shall thereafter have no right, title or interest therein. 
(Code 1982, § 30-226; Ord. No. 2465, 9-3-1993) 
Sec. 41-592. - Sewer capacity fee. 
    A sewer capacity fee is hereby established to provide revenues for the design and construction of sanitary sewer system capacity improvements. The sewer capacity fee shall be set by resolution of the city council. This fee shall apply to all property which is served by the city sanitary sewer system or which will be served when developed. The fee shall be paid either prior to issuance of a building permit or upon submittal of a request for sewer service for property whenever a building permit is not required except in the following situations: 
(1)  New sewer connections to properties that have water meter sizes of one inch and smaller. Payment of the sewer capacity fee shall not be required if the current property owner can provide documentation that the per-acre sewer tie-on charge had been paid for the property that will be served by the sewer connection. 
(2)  Properties that have an existing sewer service and the property owner requests increased water and sewer service capacity to replace the existing water and sewer service. The property owner shall only be required to pay the difference in cost between the existing meter size sewer capacity fee and the requested meter size sewer capacity fee, provided that the sewer service has not been disconnected or discontinued for more than 12 months. 
(3)  Properties not presently served by city water. The sewer capacity fee shall be based on one of the following: 
a.  The water meter size if the customer is connected to another water service; 
b.  The size of the water service line from a well; or 
c.  An estimate of water use submitted by the applicant and approved by the water utilities director, which shall be used to determine an equivalent water meter size. 
(Code 1982, § 30-227; Ord. No. 2465, 9-3-1993; Ord. No. 3056, § 2, 1-5-2009) 
Secs. 41-593-41-617. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GARBAGE AND TRASH COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 41-618. - Additional subdivision sewer development standards. 
(a)  Manholes shall be installed at the end of each sanitary sewer line except a lamphole may be installed at the end of a sanitary sewer line when the following specifications are met: 
(1)  Lamphole is at a deadend line that will never be extended and is no further than 200 feet from a manhole. 
(2)  The lamphole shall be encased in eight inches of concrete on a three-foot by three- foot pad with a minimum of eight-inch pipe constructed in a 45-degree sweep. 
(3)  All lampholes shall be covered and made watertight. 
(b)  Manholes will be constructed at all changes in grade, size, or alignment; at all intersections, and at distances not greater than 400 feet for sewers 15 inches or less, and 500 feet for sewers 18 to 30 inches. 
(Ord. No. 3028, § 2, 4-7-2008) 
Secs. 41-619-41-639. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY COLLECTION SERVICE 

Sec. 41-640. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bulky waste means solid waste, including but not limited to discarded furniture, worn-out appliances, and discarded carpet, but excluding rocks, bricks, chunks of concrete, construction debris, and automobile parts. 
    Curbside means all containers or items set out for collection by the city within five feet from the back of curb or edge of paved or graveled roadway surface. 
    Excess garbage means any amount of garbage or refuse in excess of nine standard sized items. An item shall consist of any of the following: 
(1)  Standard sized garbage bags or garbage cans; 
(2)  A bundle of yard trash which has been tied in a length of less than six fee; or 
(3)  A box not exceeding 30 inches square filled with garbage or refuse. 
The term "excess garbage" shall not include empty boxes. 
    Garbage means the animal, vegetable or other organic waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food, and any refuses, litter, rubbish, or waste, or matter of any kind or form which is uncared for, discarded, abandoned, worthless, or useless, including but not limited to paper, ashes, rags, cartons, boxes, tin cans, old clothes and shoes, broken dishes and utensils. The term "garbage" shall not include yard trash, bulky waste, rocks, bricks, chunks of concrete, construction debris, and the matter specified in section 41-651. No item of garbage set out for collection shall exceed 50 pounds in weight. 
    Houseside means all containers or items set out for collection by the city greater than five feet, but less than 100 feet from the back of curb or edge of paved or graveled roadway surface. 
    Sanitation director means the director of public works or his designee. 
    Yard trash means all types of severed vegetation, including, but not limited to leaves, grass clippings, tree branches and weeds. 
(Code 1966, § 10-31.1; Code 1982, § 30-256; Ord. No. 1217, § 1, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 2172, § 1, 1-28-1985; Ord. No. 2353, § 1, 5-22-1989; Ord. No. 2485, § 1, 8-22-1994; Ord. No. 2524, § 1, 1-15-1996) 
Sec. 41-641. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with any regulation, requirement or provision of this division or of any rule or regulation of the city manager duly promulgated hereunder shall be deemed guilty of a Class C offense. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.15; Code 1982, § 30-271; Ord. No. 1546, § 10, 12-16-1974) 
Sec. 41-642. - Containers-Generally. 
(a)  All occupants of premises within the city where garbage is produced or accumulated shall provide, for use on such premises, a sufficient number of covered, watertight, galvanized, metallic, or durable plastic containers, to adequately hold the garbage produced or accumulated on the premises between the times of garbage collection; provided, however, that it shall be the responsibility of the owner of the premises to provide such containers for all dwelling units in a dwelling containing four or more dwelling units and for all dwelling units located on premises which four or more dwelling units share. Each of such containers shall have a minimum capacity of 20 gallons and a maximum capacity of 35 gallons, and shall be equipped with handles on the sides. 
(b)  The city may furnish large capacity metal garbage containers for use on certain commercial or residential premises throughout the city. The premises upon which these containers shall be provided shall be determined by the city manager, after inspection of the premises to be served. The size, location and number of said containers to be provided shall be determined by the city manager and such determination shall be based upon the amount of garbage produced or accumulated, convenience to the occupants of the premises, and convenience to collection of garbage from the premises of the city. 
(c)  All such garbage containers, whether provided by private persons or by the city, and those which are to be located upon private property, shall be set upon paved surface pads which shall be constructed of either asphalt or concrete, and shall be placed in a location that will allow trash collection vehicles access within a reasonable distance of said garbage container. In determining the size and thickness of the pad, access distance, and the most beneficial location of same, the owner and or developer shall consult with the city manager. 
(d)  Access to the aforementioned pads shall be paved surface and free from obstructions to the movement of the containers, including but not limited to curbs, damaged or broken concrete, open ground or steep grades. 
(e)  The city shall provide notice of the requirements of this section to the owner or persons responsible for the development of premises which utilize large volume garbage containers. 
(f)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall result in the nonissuance of an occupancy permit or the discontinuance of service until such provisions are complied with, to the satisfaction of the city. 
(g)  The requirements of subsection (b) of this section may be instituted upon request for change of use, zoning, ownership, or upon a change to a permitted use within the zone which causes a substantial change of needs. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.2; Code 1982, § 30-257; Ord. No. 1217, § 2, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 1928, § 1, 4-20-1981; Ord. No. 2172, § 2, 11-28-1985) 
Sec. 41-643. - Same-Location and anchoring. 
(a)  In all areas of the city where there are open unobstructed alleys wide enough for garbage collection vehicles to travel with ease, garbage containers shall, at all times, be kept and maintained at the alley lot line on the premises served so as to be immediately accessible to the collection vehicles. In all other areas of the city, garbage containers shall, at all times, be kept and maintained not further than 100 feet from the curb or edge of the street adjacent to the premises served. No garbage shall be collected which is not contained in a container meeting the requirements of section 41-642 unless such garbage is placed at the curb or edge of the street adjacent to the premises served. Garbage containers shall, at all times, be kept sufficiently anchored to prevent their being tipped over by dogs or cats. 
(b)  All containers to be collected at houseside shall not be located inside fenced yards nor in or under carports or garages. 
(c)  All garbage containers placed at curbside for collection shall be placed within five feet from the back of curb or edge of paved or graveled surface not more than 12 hours prior to the day of collection and shall be moved off of the right-of-way before the end of the day of collection by city crews. 
(d)  In locations where it is impossible to place the containers within five feet of the curb or edge of pavement or gravel due to some obstacle, the sanitation director may designate a location that is acceptable for curbside collection. 
(Code 1966, § 10-3.3; Code 1982, § 30-258; Ord. No. 1217, § 3, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 2172, § 3, 1-28-1985; Ord. No. 2353, § 2, 5-22-1989) 
Sec. 41-644. - Same-Lids or covers. 
    The lids or covers of all garbage containers, whether provided by the occupant or owner of the premises, or furnished and owned by the city as provided in this division, shall at all times be kept fastened so that flies and other insects may not have access to the garbage contained therein, and such lids or covers shall be removed only while depositing garbage into the garbage container, or while emptying garbage therefrom. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.4; Code 1982, § 30-259; Ord. No. 1217, § 4, 7-24-1967) 
Sec. 41-645. - Same-Use of commercially manufactured garbage bags. 
    Any occupant of premises may, upon approval of the sanitation director, use a commercially manufactured disposable garbage bag; such bag shall be provided at the sole expense of such occupant. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.5; Code 1982, § 30-260; Ord. No. 1217, § 5, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 2524, § 2, 1-15-1996) 
Sec. 41-646. - Same-Maintenance. 
    Garbage containers shall, at all times, be maintained in good condition. Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this chapter or that may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof, shall be promptly replaced upon five days' written notice given by the sanitation director to the person whose responsibility it is to provide such container. The sanitation director shall have the authority to deny refuse collection services for failure to comply herewith. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.6; Code 1982, § 30-261; Ord. No. 1217, § 6, 7-24-1967) 
Sec. 41-647. - Same-Damaging, relocating or interfering with use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or otherwise interfere with the use of any trash or garbage container, or metal refuse container, publicly or privately owned, within the corporate limits of the city. No containers may be removed or relocated without permission of the sanitation director, or his authorized representative. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any garbage container owned or used by another person without the permission of the owner or person in possession of such garbage container. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.14; Code 1982, § 30-262; Ord. No. 1217, § 14, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 2172, § 4, 1-28-1985) 
Sec. 41-648. - Accumulation of yard trash. 
(a)  Yard trash shall not be deposited in said garbage containers. In all areas of the city where there are open unobstructed alleys wide enough for collection vehicles to travel with ease, said yard trash shall be placed at the alley lot line on the premises served so as to be immediately accessible to the collection vehicles. In all other areas of the city, said yard trash shall be placed at the front curb. 
(b)  Yard trash, except tree limbs, and similar yard debris, shall be placed in a sturdy container not to exceed 35 gallons in volume or 50 pounds in weight. All tree limbs and similar yard debris shall be cut so as not to exceed six feet in length and 18 inches in diameter and 50 pounds in weight, and shall be placed in containers or securely tied in separate piles at the alley lot line or front curb as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.7; Code 1982, § 30-263; Ord. No. 1217, § 7, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 2172, § 5, 1-28-1985; Ord. No. 2524, § 3, 1-15-1996) 
Sec. 41-649. - Collection, removal, and disposition. 
    All garbage produced or accumulated within the city and all yard trash, except excess garbage, shall be collected, removed, and disposed of by the city. The city manager is hereby empowered to prescribe such rules and regulations as he may deem proper, not inconsistent with the charter and city ordinances, to govern the manner and time for the collection, removal, and disposition of garbage or yard trash. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.8; Code 1982, § 30-264; Ord. No. 1217, § 8, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 2172, § 6, 1-28-1985) 
Sec. 41-650. - Burning of garbage or yard trash. 
    No person shall burn or cause to be burned any garbage or yard trash within the city without a permit or other proper authorization, in writing, from the fire chief. Such permit or authorization may be granted only for special occasions, including but not limited to pep rallies, fire training and demonstrations, or special clean-ups. Regular disposal of garbage and yard trash by open burning is specifically prohibited. Such permit or authorization will require that a competent person is constantly in attendance until such fire is extinguished. Said persons shall have a garden hose connected to the water supply, or other fire extinguishing equipment readily available for use. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.9; Code 1982, § 30-265; Ord. No. 1217, § 9, 7-24-1967) 
Sec. 41-651. - Dead animals; animal waste; grease. 
(a)  Dead animals, night soil, and similar matter shall not be allowed to accumulate or remain on any premises within the corporate limits of the city and shall be removed from the premises promptly by the occupant thereof. 
(b)  A reasonable amount of animal waste shall be collected by the city, provided that such animal waste is contained within a sealed, airtight and watertight plastic garbage bag. 
(c)  No restaurant establishment shall dispose of grease in any garbage container from which garbage is collected by the city. Any restaurant establishment causing or responsible for any grease spill occurring on public property or the public right-of-way shall be responsible for cleaning such grease spill. 
(d)  In the event that the owner or person in charge of such restaurant establishment fails to clean any grease spill, the city may clean such grease spill and charge the cost of labor and materials to such owner or person in charge. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.10; Code 1982, § 30-266; Ord. No. 1217, § 10, 7-24-1967; Ord. No. 2172, § 7, 1-28-1985) 
Sec. 41-652. - Contagious disease refuse. 
    The removal of clothing and bedding from homes or other places where highly infectious or contagious diseases have appeared shall be performed under the supervision and direction of the city-county health unit. Such clothing and bedding shall not be placed in garbage containers for collection. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.11; Code 1982, § 30-267; Ord. No. 1217, § 11, 7-24-1967) 
Sec. 41-653. - Commercial tree trimming; debris, etc. 
    Commercial tree trimmers, and those persons who trim trees and brush for hire, shall remove the same without cost to the city. All debris accumulated during the construction or remodeling of buildings shall be removed by the builder or person doing the remodeling, as the case may be, without cost to the city; provided, however, the city may dispose of such debris for an extra fee as determined by the city manager. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.13; Code 1982, § 30-268; Ord. No. 1217, § 13, 7-24-1967) 
Sec. 41-654. - Collection fees. 
    The city shall provide garbage and trash collection, removal and disposition service for the dwellings, businesses, organizations and activities at such rates and under such terms and conditions as the mayor and city council shall determine by resolution. A resolution setting rates or altering terms and conditions shall be adopted after a public hearing and shall be published in the same manner as an ordinance before becoming effective. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13.16; Code 1982, § 30-269; Ord. No. 1787, § 1, 8-14-1978; Ord. No. 1901, § 1, 6-30-1980; Ord. No. 2017, § 1, 6-28-1982; Ord. No. 2172, § 8, 1-28-1985; Ord. No. 2328, § 1, 6-27-1988; Ord. No. 2353, § 3, 5-22-1989; Ord. No. 2464, § 1, 8-23-1993) 
Sec. 41-655. - Collection and control of recyclable materials. 
    Collection of recyclable refuse items set out at the curb or other designated site as a part of a city approved or sponsored recycling program shall be controlled by the city. No person shall separate, collect, carry off, or dispose of such materials without advance approval from the city manager. 
(Code 1982, § 30-270; Ord. No. 2360, § 1, 9-18-1989; Ord. No. 2524, § 4, 1-15-1996) 
Sec. 41-656. - Private drives; wear caused by service vehicles. 
    The city shall not be liable for any normal wear or tear of private drives or private parking lots caused by sanitation service vehicles as a result of such vehicles' use of same in the ordinary course of collecting garbage, excess garbage, bulky waste, or any other refuse collected by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 30-272; Ord. No. 2172, § 9, 1-28-1985) 
Sec. 41-657. - Refuse not acceptable for collection. 
    The following shall be considered not acceptable for collection by the city: 
(1)  Materials of any kind, including ashes that contain any live coals or fire or any materials which may cause a fire; 
(2)  Materials which are hazardous to people or the environment, such as gasoline, kerosene, diesel fuel, acids, alkalies, dangerous organics, poisonous materials, radioactive substances or explosive materials; 
(3)  Dead animals; 
(4)  Materials of liquid or semi-liquid nature which are not considered hazardous as in subsection (b) of this section and are more than five gallons in quantity; 
(5)  Materials from building construction, remodeling or demolition; 
(6)  Grease from a restaurant establishment; 
(7)  Tires from vehicles, tractors, or similar equipment. 
(Code 1982, § 30-273; Ord. No. 2353, § 5, 5-22-1989; Ord. No. 2409, § 1, 8-5-1991; Ord. No. 2524, § 5, 1-15-1996) 
Sec. 41-658. - Residential oil recycling collection. 
    The city shall collect used motor oil at curbside from private residences for the purpose of recycling. Oil will only be picked up in response to a request for service. Oil is to be placed at the curb in a disposable plastic container equipped with an easily removable cap. A limit of two gallons per collection shall apply. 
(Code 1982, § 30-274; Ord. No. 2409, § 2, 8-5-1991; Ord. No. 2880, § 1, 6-6-2005) 
Secs. 41-659-41-689. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ELECTRIC UTILITY 

Sec. 41-690. - Terms and conditions of service. 
(a)  The utilities director of the electrical generation and distribution department for the city shall draft and prepare a compilation of operating terms and conditions for electric service to serve as guidelines, regulations, policies and standards for the electric customer-consumer and the electrical generation and distribution department for the receiving and furnishing of electricity by the city. 
(b)  When so prepared, the same shall be presented to the city council for acceptance by resolution, and copies of such shall be made available for interested parties, being henceforth entitled "Terms and Conditions of Service." 
(c)  Not less than three copies of the terms and conditions of service shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the electrical generation and distribution department, and when so accepted and filed, the provisions therein shall be controlling in the receiving and furnishing of electricity by the city, as if fully set out by ordinance, together with all applicable provisions of this Code, the Charter and state laws. 
(d)  Any amendments, changes, alterations, modifications or exceptions to the terms and conditions of service may be made by resolution. 
(e)  Annually, the utilities director shall prepare and submit a report to the city council concerning the use and application of the terms and conditions of service. 
(Code 1966, § 18-51; Code 1982, § 30-301; Ord. No. 1791, § 1, 10-10-1978; Ord. No. 2696, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 41-691. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a Class C offense. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-316; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977; Ord. No. 2721, § 15, 8-13-2001) 
Sec. 41-692. - Application for service. 
(a)  Any person desiring electricity or connection for electricity with the electrical generation and distribution system of the city shall make written application to the city in the office of the director of finance, ex officio city clerk. 
(b)  Said application shall contain: 
(1)  The name of the applicant; 
(2)  The legal description of the property; 
(3)  The type, kind or character of the building or structure; and 
(4)  The name of the person who will be responsible for the account-billing, with mailing address and phone number, if available. 
(c)  When the application is filed and the necessary deposit made, pursuant to the provisions of section 41-693, and an electric service charge is made in the amount of $10.00 for electric connection, the city shall have the premises inspected, and if premises are in conformance with the terms and conditions of service and applicable provisions of this Code, the application shall be approved and the necessary connections and installations shall be made. All applications, deposits, and fees required in this article shall be deposited with and made of record in the office of the director of finance, ex officio city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 18-51(B); Code 1982, § 30-302; Ord. No. 1797, § 1, 10-10-1978; Ord. No. 1845, § 1, 6-18-1979) 
Sec. 41-693. - Electric service deposits; interest; letters of credit. 
(a)  Every person making application for electric service with the city shall make a deposit in the amount of $50.00 at the time the application is made with the director of finance for purposes of guaranteeing payment of the monthly electric bill; provided, for commercial and business establishments or uses, if the average monthly electric bill for the last preceding 12-month period of electric service should exceed the amount of $50.00, the amount of deposit required for such commercial and business establishment or use shall be equal to an amount as determined to be such average monthly electric bill for the last preceding 12-month period of electric service. Provided further, for commercial and business establishments or uses, on or before the first day of the 16th month of electric service, the amount of deposit required, upon application of the establishment, shall be adjusted to an amount as determined to be such average monthly electric bill for the first 12-month period of electric service. The deposit required by this section shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum, payable on all such deposits held by the city on December 31 of each year. Interest shall be prorated from the day such deposit is made and shall be credited to the customer-consumer's electric bill next following December 31 of each year. 
(b)  In lieu of the cash deposit required by subsection (a) of this section, commercial and business establishments or uses may give an irrevocable letter of credit, designating the city as beneficiary, for purposes of guaranteeing payment of the monthly electric bill. Any letter of credit so given shall be renewed annually. Failure to keep such letter of credit current by such annual renewal shall be treated in the same manner as failure to pay a monthly electric bill, and shall result in disconnection of electric service in accordance with the provisions of section 41-699. 
(Code 1966, § 18-53; Code 1982, § 30-303; Ord. No. 1845, § 2, 6-18-1979; Ord. No. 2038, § 1, 11-8-1982; Ord. No. 2084, § 1, 8-1-1983) 
Sec. 41-694. - Rates. 
    The rates charged to customers of the Stillwater Electric Utility for electric service shall be the most recent adopted standard rate schedules currently on file and authorized for use by the Board of Trustees of the Stillwater Utilities Authority. Not less than three copies of said standard rate schedules are to be filed in the office of the city clerk, for the city, and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1966, § 18-55; Code 1982, § 30-304; Ord. No. 1775, § 1, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 2153, § 1, 9-10-1984; Ord. No. 2190, § 1, 5-13-1985; Ord. No. 2269, § 1, 10-27-1986; Ord. No. 2294, § 1, 6-29-1987) 
Sec. 41-695. - Payment of electric bill required. 
    No unauthorized person shall use electric current supplied by the city without paying for same. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-305; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-696. - Service to be metered. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to receive or use electric current from the city's electric distribution system which has not passed through a meter which meets all city specifications. The city shall have the right to enter upon premises to inspect, repair, adjust and read electric meters and the wires of the city connected thereto. 
(Code 1966, §§ 18-52, 18-62; Code 1982, § 30-306) 
Sec. 41-697. - Liability of tenants. 
(a)  All accounts for the use of light and power shall be kept against the owner of the property described for which the service was installed, providing that any tenant or any person holding property under lease may be supplied with electrical current and power on his own account when proper application is made; and in such cases, the city shall require said applicant to post a deposit with the city as may be necessary and required in any other application for utility service. 
(b)  In all cases where a tenant shall make separate application and post bond as required, then in those instances the account for the use of light and power shall be kept against the tenant and not the property owner. 
(Code 1966, § 18-57; Code 1982, § 30-307; Ord. No. 1687, § 2, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-698. - Sale of premises for which electric bill is due. 
(a)  Whenever a sale of a business is consummated between a seller and a buyer of a business which is provided electrical power by the city, and as a part of and a condition of the transaction consummated, the purchaser assumes the debts of the seller, then the purchaser of said business is hereby liable for any unpaid electrical power owed to the city, unless the seller pays same or there is sufficient deposit with the city by the seller to pay the electrical bill. In the event that said purchaser shall assume any unpaid bills to the city and shall further fail to provide for the payment of the electrical bill, and the same is not paid, the unpaid bill will be charged against utilities billed the purchaser, and electrical power will be denied unless the bill is paid in full. 
(b)  In the event that any such sale of a business is consummated and made without the city being compensated for the unpaid and outstanding electrical bill, then in that event the director of finance of the city is empowered and directed to cause electrical service to be discontinued to the purchaser after a notice is given the purchaser as provided in other delinquent utility accounts. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall apply to the purchase of a business by a purchaser at a bankruptcy sale, a receivership sale, or other sales pursuant to an order by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1966, § 18-56; Code 1982, § 30-308; Ord. No. 1687, § 1, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-699. - Electric service cut-off reconnection; dishonored checks; charges. 
(a)  Charges for electric current by meter or otherwise shall be due and payable monthly according to dates to be determined by the city, and each monthly bill shall have stamped thereon the due date period. In addition to any late payment charge assessed as provided in section 41-690, if a monthly bill is not paid within 21 days from the due date indicated thereon, an order shall be issued causing the electric service to be disconnected, discontinued or otherwise cut off for such nonpayment period. For purposes of said order, electric service shall be discontinued for any person who owes a past-due and delinquent account that is a recipient, beneficiary or consumer of electric current, whether such electric account is offered by some other name or not. 
(b)  When electric service has been disconnected, discontinued or otherwise cut-off, resumption, restoration or reconnection shall occur only upon total payment of the owing amount past due, and upon the payment of a reconnection service charge in an amount currently approved by the city council pursuant to resolution. 
(c)  In the event any electric customer-consumer of the city should offer payment for any monthly electric bill, or portion thereof, by means of a check or order which has not been honored on account of insufficient funds of the maker to pay same, or because the check or order was drawn on a closed account or on a nonexistent account, or otherwise dishonored, a check service charge in an amount approved by the city council by resolution shall be charged and collected as a service charge for proper handling and administration; provided, in the event two such dishonored checks or orders are made to the city for electric service within any last preceding 12-month period, payment of each monthly electric bill by such customer-consumer shall be made and acceptable only by certified or cashier's check, or cash. 
(d)  Electric deposits, as provided for in section 41-693, shall be held by the director of finance at all times of any customer-consumer electric service, and in the event any electric customer-consumer should desire to discontinue such electric service, the director, upon notification, shall cause such customer-consumer's account to be credited in the amount of the deposit made, the balance if any being returned. 
(e)  The director is hereby authorized, in the event a monthly bill is not paid within 21 days from the due date indicated, to cause there to be charged the amount owing against the electric deposit made, and to continue electric service without a full deposit again being made, for no longer than 21 days from the indicated due date of the next subsequent electric monthly bill; provided, should an electric deposit be applied in such manner, compliance with the provisions of section 41-693 shall again be necessary. 
(Code 1966, § 18-54; Code 1982, § 30-309; Ord. No. 1845, § 3, 6-18-1979; Ord. No. 2043, § 3, 1-3-1983; Ord. No. 2431, § 1, 6-15-1992; Ord. No. 2432, § 1, 6-15-1992) 
Sec. 41-700. - Breaking seals on meters. 
    No person shall break the seal of an electric meter. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-310; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-701. - Resale of current prohibited; use for purpose furnished required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person upon whose premises there is electrical current supplied to install additional fixtures on said premises or to apply the electrical current to purposes other than to those for which the application was originally made, or to furnish electrical current to additional persons or premises without written permission from the city. Electrical current delivered to consumers from the electrical supply lines shall be for use upon the premises of the individual consumer only, and shall not be resold or delivered for use off the premises of the consumer. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer, and is not to be resold or shared with others. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to house trailers or mobile homes, or any electrical current resold under and by virtue of a special contract entered into with the city. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-311; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-702. - Submetering. 
    No person shall allow submetering of the city's electrical transmission and distribution lines without the written approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-312; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-703. - Defacing meters, wires, etc. 
    No person shall deface, injure or destroy any electrical wire, meter, pole or other property which is part of the city's electrical transmission, generation and distribution system. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-313; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-704. - Tampering with shut-off device. 
    When electrical service has been shut off by the city, it shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to turn on or otherwise tamper with the shut-off device in any way, shape or manner. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-314; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977) 
Sec. 41-705. - Avoiding compliance with article. 
    No person shall install wiring, make connections or attach wires to service lines in a manner so that electrical current may be secured without being supplied under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 18-58; Code 1982, § 30-315; Ord. No. 1687, § 3, 3-21-1977) 
Chapter 43 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]

No. 1593, § 1, adopted Oct. 6, 1975; Ord. No. 1645, § 19, adopted June 21, 1976; Ord. No. 2068, §§ 1-6, adopted April 18, 1983; Ord. No. 2721, § 15, adopted August 13, 2001; Ord. State Law reference- Authority to regulate taxicabs, etc., 11 O.S. § 22-118. 

Sec. 43-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Taxicab means a motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire, and not operated on a fixed route. 
    Vehicle for hire means any and all motor vehicles used by any person within the corporate limits for carrying passengers for hire, or held out to the public for hire except those vehicles duly licensed by the state in interstate business. 
( Ord. No. 3298, § 1, 4-20-2015 ) 
Sec. 43-2. - Violations. 
    A violation of this chapter is a Class C offense. 
( Ord. No. 3298, § 1, 4-20-2015 ) 
Sec. 43-3. - Registration required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated any taxicab or vehicle for hire within the city unless the operator or owner of such vehicle shall have registered with the city clerk. Such registration shall be on a form prepared by the city manager in accordance with this section and shall be updated annually. The owner or operator of any taxicab or vehicle for hire operated within the city shall also file with the city clerk a certified copy of the operator or owners license issued by the Oklahoma Corporation Commission, and update said copy whenever there is any amendment or revision to the license. The annual fee for registration shall be $10.00. 
(b)  The operator of a bus as defined by 47 O.S. 1-105 shall comply with the registration requirements set forth in subsection (a), except that such operator shall not be required to file with the city clerk a copy of a license issued by the Oklahoma Corporation Commission. In lieu of such license, said operator shall file with the city clerk the following: 
(1)  Proof of liability insurance in the amount of $1,000,000.00 or greater; 
(2)  The make, model, vehicle identification number, and license tag number of each bus operated within the City of Stillwater; and 
(3)  The name, address, and drivers' license number of each bus driver employed by operator. 
Operator shall update this information as a part of annual registration renewal. 
( Ord. No. 3298, § 1, 4-20-2015 ; Ord. No. 3347, § 1, 9-12-2016 )

CODE COMPARATIVE TABLE ORDINANCES 
This table gives the location within this Code of those ordinances adopted since the 1982 Code, as updated through October 4, 2007, which are included herein. Ordinances adopted prior to such date were incorporated into the 1982 Code, as supplemented. This table contains some ordinances which precede October 4, 2007, but which were never included in the 1982 Code, as supplemented, for various reasons. Ordinances adopted since October 4, 2007, and not listed herein, have been omitted as repealed, superseded or not a general and permanent nature.
